texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A question I'm asked daily is “How can I find out what is generating iowait on my server?” Sure, you can dig through pages of lsof output, restart services, or run strace, but it can be a frustrating process. I saw a process on  this blog post , and I changed the regexes to fit Red Hat and CentOS systems a bit better:
texts.text: A question I'm asked daily is “How can I find out what is generating iowait on my server?” Sure, you can dig through pages of lsof output, restart services, or run strace, but it can be a frustrating process. I saw a process on  this blog post , and I changed the regexes to fit Red Hat and CentOS systems a bit better:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /etc/init.d/syslog stop
# echo 1 > /proc/sys/vm/block_dump
# dmesg | egrep "READ|WRITE|dirtied" | egrep -o '([a-zA-Z]*)' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | head
   1526 mysqld
    819 httpd
    429 kjournald
     35 qmail
     27 in
      7 imapd
      6 irqbalance
      5 pop
      4 pdflush
      3 spamc
texts.text:
# /etc/init.d/syslog stop
# echo 1 > /proc/sys/vm/block_dump
# dmesg | egrep "READ|WRITE|dirtied" | egrep -o '([a-zA-Z]*)' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | head
   1526 mysqld
    819 httpd
    429 kjournald
     35 qmail
     27 in
      7 imapd
      6 irqbalance
      5 pop
      4 pdflush
      3 spamc

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In my specific situation, it looks like MySQL is the biggest abuser of my disk, followed by Apache and the filesystem journaling. As expected, qmail is a large contender, too.
texts.text: In my specific situation, it looks like MySQL is the biggest abuser of my disk, followed by Apache and the filesystem journaling. As expected, qmail is a large contender, too.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Don't forget to set things back to their normal state when you're done!
texts.text: Don't forget to set things back to their normal state when you're done!
